SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this QUESTIONNAIRE:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires all I would be able to answer
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

A work of explanation to the questionnaire

It is difficult to answer a general questionnaire on pioneer life's experiences.

Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience. Others may have been applicable at one time or another, but do not worry about having to answer them all.

If there is no space sufficient to answer a question, please put a check mark here.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1941, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or reply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1 entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would like to do so, please put a check mark here and one will be sent to you.

A later date, some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Reading the old public press, hearing people talk, hearing from experience.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   Though it would be all right to see if I liked it in Canada, they regretted coming here.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
    By myself

13. What means of transportation did you use?
    By train

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
    Stayed for a while at Winnipeg then decided to come out here

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
    For a short time at Rosetown as the ferry could not go early in the spring. Came here by boat and on team hitched together by two nights.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
    Work homestead S.E. sec 4-39-20 W.2nd 3W.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
    About two years in British Columbia
    1946 to 48

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
    Farming in Minnesota. Several years at Amisk. First four years after that farming until 1942 then they retired.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought it was a good idea.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)? By myself.

13. What means of transportation did you use? By train.

14. What incidents of the Journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences.) I stayed in a hotel at Winnipeg then drove to Brandon.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? In a hotel in Brandon.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? I settled in Brandon.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. British Columbia.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I was president of the Anaheim Rural Telephone Co. for 24 years, trustee of the post over thirty years, Trustee and secretary of Anaheim school district for many years and held other minor offices at times.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

Philip Junk owned the first combine fall of 1946 and myself.

Philip J. Hoffman bought the first car on the Sunday via 1915, mine was model T Ford.

Emil Zachmuth helped the settlers build the first house made of logs in the fall of 1903.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Our Dominic Hoffman suggested the name for our school district. Anaheim was named after St. Ann mother of the blessed virgin. The first mass was celebrated on her feast day July 26th 1903.
